facts.text: Mortgage bond dated 8th April 1927 (21st Chaitra 1334 Fasli), written and engrossed at plaintiffs' house in village Chakla Maulanagur.
Executants (mortgagors, defendants first party, residents of Chandpur) put signatures on the bond on 12th April 1927.
Bond registered on 12th April 1927 at Katihar before Registering Officer; presented same day, executants admitted execution there.
Due date for payment in mortgage bond: 6th March 1928.
Four attesting witnesses: Sunderlal, Matukdhari Prasad, Dwarka Prasad, Nanak Prasad (scribe); all residents of Chakla Maulanagur.
Payment of Rs. 300 made on 21st January 1928 (before due date).
Payment of Rs. 75 made on 5th June 1929.
Payment made on 8th March 1931.
Payment made on 3rd April 1931.
Two payments made in May 1932.
Payment made on 25th July 1934.
Last payment of part of Rs. 780-9-0 total made on 15th May 1936.
Suit instituted on 4th March 1940 as Title Mortgage Suit No. 7 of 1940 by plaintiffs for enforcement of simple mortgage by sale.

Subordinate Judge of Purnea decree dated 27th February 1942: Bond not legally attested, refused sale decree, passed personal money decree against first party defendants; limitation saved by payments under s.20 Limitation Act.
Defendants (mortgagors) appealed to Patna High Court as F.A. No. 47 of 1942; no appeal or cross-objection by plaintiffs.
Patna High Court (Fazl Ali C.J., Beevor J.) judgment dated 17th March 1944: Bond duly attested and enforceable as mortgage; suit within time; affirmed trial decree as no cross-appeal by plaintiffs.
Appeal to Privy Council on special leave (Order in Council 2nd August 1946), transferred to Supreme Court.
Attesting witnesses Sunderlal (P.W.1) and Matukdhari Prasad examined; stated bond written, signed by executants, attested same day at plaintiffs' house.
Defendant No.1 Sant Lall stated execution at Katihar, not plaintiffs' village.
Written statement para 15 by defendants 1-3 admits payments listed in plaint and claims additional payments.
Plaint originally prayed only for mortgage decree; amended after hearing to include personal remedy saved by payments.

legal_issues.text: Whether the mortgage bond was legally attested under the law.
Whether the suit for personal money decree was barred by limitation under Article 116 Limitation Act, or saved by payments under section 20 Limitation Act.
Whether the High Court or Supreme Court can grant mortgage decree despite no appeal or cross-objection by plaintiffs, under Order 41 Rule 33 CPC.

petitioner_arguments.text: Even if bond effective as mortgage, no personal money decree possible unless suit within Article 116 Limitation Act (6 years from due date); High Court overlooked this.
Payments not acknowledged in handwriting or signed writing by payers as required by proviso to section 20 Limitation Act; written statement admission insufficient.
Bond not legally attested; Subordinate Judge's finding correct based on evidence; attesting witnesses signed before execution.

respondent_arguments.text: High Court correctly found bond duly attested and enforceable as mortgage; suit within time for mortgage enforcement.
Even without appeal/cross-objection, High Court/SC can grant mortgage decree under Order 41 Rule 33 CPC based on its findings.

court_reasoning.text: For section 20 Limitation Act, payment must be within limitation period and acknowledged in handwriting or signed by payer; acknowledgment must exist before suit institution; plaint must allege it; written statement admission post-plaint insufficient.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No written acknowledgment of payments prior to suit; amended plaint lacks averment of acknowledgment; suit barred for personal decree.

court_reasoning.text: Bond not properly attested: written/engrossed 8th April at plaintiffs' house, attesting witnesses signed there same day; executants signed 12th April at Katihar before registration; attestation before execution invalid.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Witnesses distinguished writing from execution; probabilities support execution at Katihar.

court_reasoning.text: Since no proper attestation, no mortgage; personal decree barred by limitation; no mortgage decree possible.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Trial court erred on limitation but correct on attestation; High Court reversed attestation wrongly.

holdings.text: Suit for personal money decree barred by limitation as no qualifying acknowledgment under section 20 proviso existed before suit.
Mortgage bond not legally attested as witnesses signed before executants.

precedents_cited.relevance: Acknowledgment under s.20 need not be within limitation period but must exist before suit.
Supports view on timing of acknowledgment under s.20.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs limitation for personal decree on registered bond (6 years from due date); part payments extend if acknowledged in writing signed by payer.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Appellate court power to grant relief not claimed if necessary; plaint must state limitation exemption grounds.

statutes_cited.name: Limitation Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Court must dismiss time-barred suits regardless of plea.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court allowed the appeal, set aside the money decree of the courts below as the suit for personal relief was barred by limitation due to lack of prior written acknowledgment of payments; held bond not properly attested, reversing High Court on that point.
outcome.relief_granted: Appeal allowed; money decree set aside; no mortgage decree granted.

key_quotes.text: "Unless, therefore, there is acknowledgment in the required form, the payment by itself is of no avail."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on requirement for written acknowledgment under s.20 Limitation Act.

key_quotes.text: "The ground of exemption is not complete without this second element, and unless both these elements are proved to exist at the date of the filing of the plaint the suit would be held to be time-barred."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why post-plaint admissions insufficient for limitation.

key_quotes.text: "the attesting witnesses must have signed the deed before it was executed and this was not attestation in the eye of law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
